about.author:
About the author

Luis Villegas learnt algorithms and data structures with the C++ programming language in college back in 2017. Since then, he has not stopped learning technologies and programming languages mostly related to the web, with great online course platforms such as W3Schools and FreeCodeCamp, where he learnt HTML, CSS and modern JavaScript with React and Redux. He quickly became a web developer for both server-side and client-side applications, with the Golang programming language for the backend and React and Redux or Svelte for the frontend, or simply HTML, CSS and JS with HUGO for static sites.

This application is a demonstration of his skills as a web developer. The API, built with Golang is running on an AWS EC2 instance and the frontend, which supports i18n, is built with React and Redux and is being hosted on Netlify.
about.contact: You can get in touch with him through his email: luisguveal@gmail.com or his LinkedIn profile: https://linkedin.com/in/luisg-villegas
about.intro1: DollarBlacklist is a reputation system for USD currency bills, where users can query banknotes by their serial number, value and series year, and immediately see a summary of the reviews that other users have made on the banknote, and thus determine with the greatest possible security the authenticity of the bill.
about.intro2: In addition to providing a summary of reviews made by other users, DollarBlacklist lists the security features that the bill consulted should have, and how to use them to determine whether the bill is real or counterfeit.
about.motivation:
Motivation

Many people don't really know how to spot fake bills by inspecting their security features. The official website of the US currency does list them in several PDF files, but that's not the most practical way to learn all the security features from all the denominations from all the series years.

Counterfeit bill detectors already exist, but they are an overkill for something that could be easily done by humans simply by analizing the security features. They were created for a reason: to make replicating them very difficult and expensive, and not everyone can afford to buy one of those machines, which are not as portable as smartphones.
about.reviews:
Reviews

There are two types of reviews:

  • Good review: authentic banknotes

    Users can leave an optional public comment and must specify a number from 1 to 5, which refers to the physical conditions of the banknote.

  • Bad review: counterfeit banknotes

    Users can leave an optional public comment and must specify the defects of the banknote that are considered a failure in the security features.
about.reviewsNotes:
Important: in order to submit reviews, users must allow DollarBlacklist to know their location, since this information is an essential part of the review, and is used to position on a map the city where the review was performed.

A user is only allowed to submit one review of one type (good or bad) of a single banknote.
about.securityFeatures:
About the security features

Each banknote denomination has different security features, which vary depending on the series year.

All information regarding the security features of the banknotes of each denomination of each serial year has been obtained from the official website of the U.S. currency: www.uscurrency.gov
about.users:
Types of users

There are two types of users:

  • Regular
  • Business

The only difference between both types of users is that the reviews made by businesses in general are more reliable than those made by regular users.

business.body:
Business accounts have more credibility in terms of banknote reviews than regular user accounts, so businesses need to prove us that they really are.

In this page, we assume that we ask the user for some data in a form, as well as his mail. An administrator will verify the data, generate a business registration link and mail it to the user.
business.heading: Are you a business? Give us some information to verify

learn.heading: Learn how to identify a counterfeit banknote

markers.businessBadReviews: {n, plural, =1 {# business indicated defects on this banknote} other {# businesses indicated defects on this banknote}}
markers.businessGoodReviews: {n, plural, =1 {# business authenticated this banknote} other {# businesses authenticated this banknote}}
markers.userBadReviews: {n, plural, =1 {# user indicated defects on this banknote} other {# users indicated defects on this banknote}}
markers.userGoodReviews: {n, plural, =1 {# user authenticated this banknote} other {# users authenticated this banknote}}

nav.business: Are you a business? Signup here

query.label: query banknote
query.tip: Tip: leave the serial number empty if you just want to see the security features

review.businessBadReviews: {n, plural, =1 {# business indicated} other {# businesses indicated}} defects on this banknote
review.businessGoodReviews: {n, plural, =1 {# business indicated} other {# businesses indicated}} that this banknote is authentic
review.defectsHeading: Users found the following defects on this banknote
review.moreInfo: Login to see more information about who reviewed this banknote
review.myBadReview: You indicated some defects on this banknote on {date}
review.myGoodReview: You indicated that this banknote has no defects on {date} with a rating of {rating}
review.noReviews: This banknote has no reviews yet.
review.userBadReviews: {n, plural, =1 {# user indicated} other {# users indicated}} defects on this banknote
review.userGoodReviews: {n, plural, =1 {# user indicated} other {# users indicated}} that this banknote is authentic

reviewForm.alreadyReviewed: You are allowed to submit only one review per banknote
reviewForm.askForLogin: Login to send a review of this note
reviewForm.defectsHeading: Indicate the defects on this banknote
reviewForm.indicateDefects: You must indicate at least one defect
reviewForm.label: Send a review

features.desc: A black seal to the left of the portrait which bears the name and corresponding letter of the distributing Federal Reserve Bank.
features.label: Black seal

features.desc: Move your finger along the note’s surface to feel the raised printing, which gives genuine Federal Reserve notes their distinctive texture.
features.label: Raised printing

features.desc: Federal Reserve note paper is one-fourth linen and three-fourths cotton, and contains red and blue security fibers.
features.label: Paper

features.desc: The $1 note features a portrait of George Washington on the front of the note. The vignette on the back of the note features the Great Seal of the United States.
features.label: Portrait and vignette

features.desc: A seal to the right of the portrait represents the U.S. Department of the Treasury.
features.label: Green Seal

features.desc: A combination of eleven numbers and letters appears twice on the front of the note.
features.label: Serial numbers

possibleDefects.desc: The seal of the Federal Reserve Bank is wrong or is not in the right place.
possibleDefects.label: Black seal

possibleDefects.desc: The note doesn't have raised printing on the surface.
possibleDefects.label: Raised printing

possibleDefects.desc: The papel is wrong or doesn't contain small red and blue fibers.
possibleDefects.label: Paper

possibleDefects.desc: The portrait or the vignette are wrong.
possibleDefects.label: Portrait and vignette

possibleDefects.desc: The seal of the U.S. Department of the Treasury is wrong or isn't in the right place.
possibleDefects.label: Green seal

possibleDefects.desc: The serial numbers are badly printed or don't have the right format.
possibleDefects.label: Serial numbers

keyFeatures.desc: Hold the note to light to see an embedded thread running vertically to the left of the Federal Reserve Bank seal. The thread is imprinted with the letters USA and the word TEN in an alternating pattern and is visible from both sides of the note. The thread glows orange when illuminated by ultraviolet light.
keyFeatures.label: Security thread

keyFeatures.desc: Look carefully (magnification may be necessary) to see the small printed words THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA along the outer edge of the portrait’s oval frame.
keyFeatures.label: Microprinting

possibleDefects.desc: The thread is not embedded, doesn't have the right format or doesn't glow orange when illuminated by ultraviolet light.
possibleDefects.label: Security thread

possibleDefects.desc: The small words THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA are not along the outer edge of the portrait’s oval frame, or are badly printed.
possibleDefects.label: Microprinting

keyFeatures.label: Security thread

keyFeatures.desc: Tilt the note back and forth while focusing on the blue ribbon. You will see the bells change to 100s as they move. When you tilt the note back and forth, the bells and 100s move side to side. If you tilt it side to side, they move up and down. The ribbon is woven into the paper, not printed on it.
keyFeatures.label: 3D security ribbon

keyFeatures.desc: Hold the note to light and look for a faint image of Benjamin Franklin in the blank space to the right of the portrait. The image is visible from both sides of the note.
keyFeatures.label: Watermark

keyFeatures.desc: Tilt the note to see the numeral 100 in the lower right corner of the front of the note shift from copper to green. The same goes for the bell in the inkwell.
keyFeatures.label: Color-shifting ink

features.desc: Federal Reserve note paper is one-fourth linen and three-fourths cotton, and contains red and blue security fibers.
features.label: Paper

features.desc: The note includes subtle background colors of blue and red to both sides of the note.
features.label: Color

features.desc: The $50 note features a portrait of President Grant on the front of the note. The vignette on the back of the note features the United States Capitol.
features.label: Portrait and vignette

features.desc: Representative of the United States flag, a field of blue stars is located to the left of the portrait, while three red stripes are located to the right of the portrait. A small metallic silver-blue star is located on the lower right side of the portrait.
features.label: Symbols of freedom

features.desc: A seal to the right of the portrait represents the U.S. Department of the Treasury.
features.label: Green Seal

features.desc: A unique combination of eleven numbers and letters appears twice on the front of the note.
features.label: Serial numbers

keyFeatures.desc: Hold the note to light to see an embedded thread running vertically to the right of the portrait. The thread is imprinted with the text USA 50 and a small flag in an alternating pattern and is visible from both sides of the note. The thread glows yellow when illuminated by ultraviolet light.
keyFeatures.label: Security thread

keyFeatures.desc: Hold the note to light and look for a faint image of President Grant in the blank space to the right of the portrait. The image is visible from both sides of the note.
keyFeatures.label: Watermark

keyFeatures.desc: Tilt the note to see the numeral 50 in the lower right corner on the front of the note shift from copper to green.
keyFeatures.label: Color-shifting ink

possibleDefects.desc: The thread is not embedded, doesn't have the right format or doesn't glow yellow when illuminated by ultraviolet light.
possibleDefects.label: Security thread

possibleDefects.desc: The watermark is not in the right place, isn't visible from both sides or doesn't match the portrait.
possibleDefects.label: Watermark

possibleDefects.desc: The ink doesn't shift from copper to green.
possibleDefects.label: Color-shifting ink

possibleDefects.desc: The seal of the Federal Reserve System is wrong or is not in the right place.
possibleDefects.label: Black seal

possibleDefects.desc: Some of the small words are not in the right place or are badly printed.
possibleDefects.label: Microprinting

possibleDefects.desc: The banknote doesn't have raised printing on the surface.
possibleDefects.label: Raised printing

possibleDefects.desc: The papel is wrong or doesn't contain small red and blue fibers.
possibleDefects.label: Paper

possibleDefects.desc: The colors in the background are wrong.
possibleDefects.label: Color

possibleDefects.desc: The portrait or the vignette are wrong.
possibleDefects.label: Portrait and vignette

possibleDefects.desc: Some of the symbols in the background are missing or are badly printed.
possibleDefects.label: Symbols of freedom

possibleDefects.desc: The seal of the U.S. Department of the Treasury is wrong or isn't in the right place.
possibleDefects.label: Green seal

possibleDefects.desc: The serial numbers are badly printed or don't have the right format.
possibleDefects.label: Serial numbers
